creditline: Gift of Joan B. Mirviss and Robert J. Levine
description: round clay body with no glaze on exterior; incised lines in wavy, snake-like bands; each band is divided into smaller scale-like sections with a dot at the center; white slip (?) in crevices; vessel has a wider shoulder with a narrower base and mouth; tan color glazed interior; orange cloth wrap; natural color storage box with lid and brown tie
inscription: Box lid recto: 彫文炻壺 {chōmon seki tsubo} (stoneware jar with incised pattern). Signed: 加守田章二 {Kamoda Shōji}, with red seal: 章 {Shō}.
text: For Kamoda, the early 1970s were a period of intense artistic activity and experimentation. No sooner would he receive acclaim for a new way of embellishing his vessels than he would move on to develop yet another approach. Here, he modified his wave patterns by carving them as overlapping scales. Though this jar is unglazed, he pigmented other works featuring the scale-like waves with colored glazes.
title: Stoneware jar with incised pattern
